question_text: Name the following halides according to IUPAC system and classify them as alkyl, allyl, benzyl (primary, secondary, tertiary), vinyl or aryl halides: (i) (CH₃)₂CHCH(Cl)CH₃, (ii) CH₃CH₂CH(CH₃)CH(C₂H₅)Cl, (iii) CH₃CH₂C(CH₃)₂CH₂I, (iv) (CH₃)₃CCH₂CH(Br)C₆H₅, (v) CH₃CH(CH₃)CH(Br)CH₃, (vi) CH₃C(C₂H₅)₂CH₂Br, (vii) CH₃C(Cl)(C₂H₅)CH₂CH₃, (viii) CH₃CH=C(Cl)CH₂CH(CH₃)₂, (ix) CH₃CH=CHC(Br)(CH₃)₂, (x) p-ClC₆H₄CH₂CH(CH₃)₂, (xi) m-ClCH₂C₆H₄CH₂C(CH₃)₃, (xii) o-Br-C₆H₄CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃.
correct_answer: A detailed list of IUPAC names with proper classification for each compound as per the rules for alkyl, allylic, benzylic, vinyl and aryl halides. (For example, (i) would be named as 2-Chloro-3-methylpentane and classified as a secondary alkyl halide, etc.)
explanation: Each compound must be analyzed by identifying the longest carbon chain, the position of the halogen and other substituents, and then applying IUPAC nomenclature. The classification depends on the nature of the carbon atom to which the halogen is attached (sp³ for alkyl, allylic, benzylic; sp² for vinyl and aryl).

question_text: Give the IUPAC names of the following compounds: (i) CH₃CH(Cl)CH(Br)CH₃, (ii) CHF₂CBrClF, (iii) ClCH₂C≡CCH₂Br, (iv) (CCl₃)₃CCl, (v) CH₃C(p-ClC₆H₄)₂CH(Br)CH₃, (vi) (CH₃)₃CCH=CClC₆H₄I-p.
correct_answer: The IUPAC names determined by applying the priority rules for functional groups and numbering. For instance, (i) is 2-Bromo-3-chlorobutane and the other compounds are named similarly by systematic application of the nomenclature rules.
explanation: By drawing the structures, assigning locants for substituents, and then following the IUPAC rules (including the use of prefixes, numbering, and proper designation of substituents), the correct names can be determined.

question_text: Write the structures of the following organic halogen compounds: (i) 2-Chloro-3-methylpentane, (ii) p-Bromochlorobenzene, (iii) 1-Chloro-4-ethylcyclohexane, (iv) 2-(2-Chlorophenyl)-1-iodooctane, (v) 2-Bromobutane, (vi) 4-tert-Butyl-3-iodoheptane, (vii) 1-Bromo-4-sec-butyl-2-methylbenzene, (viii) 1,4-Dibromobut-2-ene.
correct_answer: The corresponding structural formulas showing correct placement of the halogen atoms, substituents, and double bonds as indicated by the names.
explanation: Convert the IUPAC names into structural formulas. This requires understanding of how to interpret locants, substituents, and cyclic or acyclic structures from the names provided.

question_text: Which one of the following has the highest dipole moment? (i) CH₂Cl₂, (ii) CHCl₃, (iii) CCl₄.
correct_answer: CH₂Cl₂
explanation: CH₂Cl₂ has a tetrahedral structure with two chlorines and two hydrogens arranged such that the bond dipoles do not cancel completely, resulting in a higher net dipole moment compared to the more symmetrical CHCl₃ and nonpolar CCl₄.

question_text: A hydrocarbon C₅H₁₀ does not react with chlorine in dark but gives a single monochloro compound C₅H₉Cl in bright sunlight. Identify the hydrocarbon.
correct_answer: Cyclopentane
explanation: Alkanes require light to undergo free radical substitution. In cyclopentane, all hydrogens are equivalent, so free radical chlorination under photolytic conditions yields a single monochloro derivative, whereas in the dark no reaction occurs.

question_text: Write the isomers of the compound having formula C₄H₉Br.
correct_answer: n-Butyl bromide, sec-Butyl bromide, isobutyl bromide, and tert-Butyl bromide
explanation: C₄H₉Br can exist as four isomeric forms based on the structure of the butyl group. The isomers differ in the position of the bromine atom and the branching of the carbon chain.

question_text: Write the equations for the preparation of 1-iodobutane from (i) 1-butanol, (ii) 1-chlorobutane, (iii) but-1-ene.
correct_answer: (i) CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂OH + HI → CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂I + H₂O (often via treatment with SOCl₂ followed by NaI), (ii) CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂Cl + NaI (in dry acetone) → CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂I + NaCl, (iii) CH₂=CHCH₂CH₃ + HI (with peroxides for anti-Markovnikov addition) → CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂I.
explanation: 1-Iodobutane can be prepared by substitution reactions. In (i) an alcohol is converted to an iodide via an acid or thionyl chloride route followed by nucleophilic substitution, in (ii) a halogen exchange reaction (Finkelstein reaction) is used, and in (iii) hydrohalogenation under anti-Markovnikov conditions (presence of peroxides) ensures the iodine attaches to the terminal carbon.

question_text: What are ambident nucleophiles? Explain with an example.
correct_answer: Ambident nucleophiles are nucleophiles that have two different sites from which they can donate an electron pair. An example is the cyanide ion (CN⁻), which can attack through either the carbon (forming an alkyl cyanide) or the nitrogen (forming an isocyanide).
explanation: The term 'ambident' refers to species capable of reacting via two different atoms, leading to different products. In the case of CN⁻, the preference for attack through carbon or nitrogen depends on the reaction conditions and the nature (ionic or covalent) of the nucleophile.

question_text: Which compound in each of the following pairs will react faster in SN2 reaction with –OH? (i) CH₃Br or CH₃I, (ii) (CH₃)₃CCl or CH₃Cl.
correct_answer: (i) CH₃I reacts faster than CH₃Br, (ii) CH₃Cl reacts faster than (CH₃)₃CCl.
explanation: In SN2 reactions, a better leaving group and lower steric hindrance promote faster reaction. Iodide is a better leaving group than bromide. Additionally, CH₃Cl is less hindered than the tertiary (CH₃)₃CCl, making it more reactive toward SN2.

question_text: Predict all the alkenes that would be formed by dehydrohalogenation of the following halides with sodium ethoxide in ethanol and identify the major alkene: (i) 1-Bromo-1-methylcyclohexane, (ii) 2-Chloro-2-methylbutane, (iii) 2,2,3-Trimethyl-3-bromopentane.
correct_answer: For each substrate, elimination occurs following Zaitsev's rule. The predicted alkenes are the set of possible regioisomers from β-elimination. The major product is the alkene with the most substituted double bond (highest stability).
explanation: Dehydrohalogenation proceeds via elimination (E2) reaction; multiple β-hydrogen positions might yield different alkenes. However, the major product corresponds to the more substituted (and more stable) alkene according to Zaitsev's rule.

question_text: How will you bring about the following conversions? (i) Ethanol to but-1-yne, (ii) Ethane to bromoethene, (iii) Propene to 1-nitropropane, (iv) Toluene to benzyl alcohol, (v) Propene to propyne, (vi) Ethanol to ethyl fluoride, (vii) Bromomethane to propanone, (viii) But-1-ene to but-2-ene, (ix) 1-Chlorobutane to n-octane, (x) Benzene to biphenyl.
correct_answer: Each conversion requires a specific sequence of reactions such as oxidation, substitution, elimination, or coupling reactions. For example, to convert ethanol to but-1-yne one method involves conversion to a haloalkane followed by a double elimination reaction; benzene to biphenyl involves a coupling reaction (e.g., the Ullmann reaction).
explanation: These conversions involve planning a synthetic route using known organic reactions. The appropriate reagents and conditions must be selected based on the functional group transformations described in the chapter.

question_text: Explain why (i) the dipole moment of chlorobenzene is lower than that of cyclohexyl chloride, (ii) alkyl halides, though polar, are immiscible with water, (iii) Grignard reagents should be prepared under anhydrous conditions.
correct_answer: (i) In chlorobenzene, the chlorine atom’s lone pairs participate in resonance with the benzene ring, reducing the net dipole moment, whereas in cyclohexyl chloride such resonance is absent. (ii) Alkyl halides are nonpolar overall because the polar C–X bond is not enough to overcome the strong hydrogen bonding among water molecules, making them immiscible. (iii) Grignard reagents react readily with water; even trace moisture will quench them, hence preparations must be anhydrous.
explanation: The dipole moment differences arise from resonance and molecular geometry. The immiscibility is due to the inability of alkyl halides to disrupt water’s hydrogen-bond network, and the extreme reactivity of Grignard reagents toward protic substances necessitates dry conditions.
topic: Physical Properties and Reactions of Haloalkanes

question_text: Give the uses of freon 12, DDT, carbon tetrachloride and iodoform.
correct_answer: Freon 12 is used as a refrigerant and in aerosol propellants; DDT is used as an insecticide (although its use is now restricted in many countries); carbon tetrachloride has been used as a solvent, cleaning agent, and in the manufacture of refrigerants; iodoform was used as an antiseptic.
explanation: These compounds have industrial, agricultural, and medicinal applications based on their physical and chemical properties. However, environmental and health concerns have limited their use in recent years.

question_text: Write the structure of the major organic product in each of the following reactions: (i) CH₃CH₂CH₂Cl + NaI (acetone, heat) → ?, (ii) (CH₃)₃CBr + KOH (ethanol, heat) → ?, (iii) CH₃CH(Br)CH₂CH₃ + NaOH (water) → ?, (iv) CH₃CH₂Br + KCN (aq. ethanol) → ?, (v) C₆H₅ONa + C₂H₅Cl → ?, (vi) CH₃CH₂CH₂OH + SOCl₂ → ?, (vii) CH₃CH₂CH=CH₂ + HBr (peroxide) → ?, (viii) CH₃CH=C(CH₃)₂ + HBr → ?
correct_answer: The products are: (i) CH₃CH₂CH₂Cl substituted by I giving CH₃CH₂CH₂I via Finkelstein reaction; (ii) elimination leading to an alkene from tert-butyl bromide is less common, but typically, KOH in ethanol causes elimination to form isobutene derivatives; (iii) substitution to yield CH₃CH(OH)CH₂CH₃; (iv) formation of CH₃CH₂CN; (v) formation of ethyl phenyl ether (C₆H₅OC₂H₅); (vi) conversion of the alcohol to the corresponding chloride CH₃CH₂CH₂Cl; (vii) anti-Markovnikov addition of HBr to form 1-bromobutane; (viii) addition of HBr according to Markovnikov rule to yield a brominated alkane.
explanation: Each reaction proceeds via a specific mechanism (Finkelstein halogen exchange, nucleophilic substitution, elimination, addition, etc.) leading to the major organic product. The conditions and reagents dictate whether substitution or elimination occurs.

question_text: Write the mechanism of the following reaction: nBuBr + KCN (EtOH-H₂O) → nBuCN.
correct_answer: The reaction proceeds via an SN2 mechanism where the cyanide ion performs a backside attack on the n-butyl bromide, leading to inversion of configuration and substitution of Br by CN to form n-butyl cyanide.
explanation: In SN2 reactions, the nucleophile attacks the electrophilic carbon from the side opposite to the leaving group in a single concerted step. The use of a polar protic solvent like EtOH-H₂O facilitates this process by solvating the leaving group and stabilizing the transition state.

question_text: Arrange the compounds of each set in order of reactivity towards SN2 displacement: (i) 2-Bromo-2-methylbutane, 1-Bromopentane, 2-Bromopentane; (ii) 1-Bromo-3-methylbutane, 2-Bromo-2-methylbutane, 2-Bromo-3-methylbutane; (iii) 1-Bromobutane, 1-Bromo-2,2-dimethylpropane, 1-Bromo-2-methylbutane, 1-Bromo-3-methylbutane.
correct_answer: For SN2 reactions, the order of reactivity is highest for the least sterically hindered substrate. Thus, (i) 1-Bromopentane > 2-Bromopentane > 2-Bromo-2-methylbutane; (ii) 1-Bromo-3-methylbutane > 2-Bromo-3-methylbutane > 2-Bromo-2-methylbutane; (iii) 1-Bromobutane > 1-Bromo-3-methylbutane > 1-Bromo-2-methylbutane > 1-Bromo-2,2-dimethylpropane.
explanation: SN2 reactivity is strongly affected by steric hindrance. Primary halides react faster than secondary, and tertiary halides are essentially unreactive under SN2 conditions. The order is deduced by comparing the degree of substitution and bulkiness around the electrophilic center.

question_text: Out of C₆H₅CH₂Cl and C₆H₅CHClC₆H₅, which is more easily hydrolysed by aqueous KOH?
correct_answer: C₆H₅CH₂Cl (benzyl chloride) is more easily hydrolysed.
explanation: Benzyl chloride has the halogen attached to a benzylic position, which is more reactive due to stabilization of the intermediate via resonance, whereas C₆H₅CHClC₆H₅ is more hindered and less reactive towards nucleophilic attack by hydroxide.

question_text: p-Dichlorobenzene has higher m.p. than those of o- and m-isomers. Discuss.
correct_answer: The higher melting point of p-dichlorobenzene is due to its higher molecular symmetry which allows for better packing in the crystal lattice compared to the o- and m-isomers.
explanation: Although the boiling points of isomeric dihalobenzenes are similar, the melting point is sensitive to crystal packing. The para isomer, being more symmetrical, packs more efficiently, leading to a higher melting point.

question_text: How can the following conversions be carried out? (i) Propene to propan-1-ol, (ii) Ethanol to but-1-yne, (iii) 1-Bromopropane to 2-bromopropane, (iv) Toluene to benzyl alcohol, (v) Benzene to 4-bromonitrobenzene, (vi) Benzyl alcohol to 2-phenylethanoic acid, (vii) Ethanol to propanenitrile, (viii) Aniline to chlorobenzene, (ix) 2-Chlorobutane to 3,4-dimethylhexane, (x) 2-Methyl-1-propene to 2-chloro-2-methylpropane, (xi) Ethyl chloride to propanoic acid, (xii) But-1-ene to n-butyliodide, (xiii) 2-Chloropropane to 1-propanol, (xiv) Isopropyl alcohol to iodoform, (xv) Chlorobenzene to p-nitrophenol, (xvi) 2-Bromopropane to 1-bromopropane, (xvii) Chloroethane to butane, (xviii) Benzene to diphenyl, (xix) tert-Butyl bromide to isobutyl bromide, (xx) Aniline to phenylisocyanide.
correct_answer: Each conversion requires a specific reaction sequence involving substitutions, eliminations, oxidations, reductions, coupling or rearrangement reactions. Detailed synthetic pathways must be proposed using methods such as hydrolysis, halogen exchange, free radical reactions, electrophilic aromatic substitution, Grignard reactions etc.
explanation: The answer involves planning detailed synthetic schemes for each conversion by applying various organic transformation reactions described in the chapter. These require knowledge of reaction mechanisms and choice of appropriate reagents and conditions.

question_text: The treatment of alkyl chlorides with aqueous KOH leads to the formation of alcohols but in the presence of alcoholic KOH, alkenes are major products. Explain.
correct_answer: Aqueous KOH acts as a nucleophile promoting substitution to form alcohols, while alcoholic KOH acts as a strong base promoting dehydrohalogenation (elimination) to yield alkenes.
explanation: The solvent determines the reaction pathway. In water, nucleophilic substitution is favored because hydroxide ions are solvated and act as nucleophiles. In alcoholic solution, the basicity of KOH is enhanced, and elimination (E2) becomes the predominant pathway.

question_text: Primary alkyl halide C₄H₉Br (a) reacted with alcoholic KOH to give compound (b). Compound (b) is reacted with HBr to give (c) which is an isomer of (a). When (a) is reacted with sodium metal it gives compound (d), C₈H₁₈ which is different from the compound formed when n-butyl bromide is reacted with sodium. Give the structural formula of (a) and write the equations for all the reactions.
correct_answer: For example, (a) can be n-butyl bromide (CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₂Br). Its reaction with alcoholic KOH yields but-1-ene (b). Addition of HBr to but-1-ene under appropriate conditions (with Markovnikov or anti-Markovnikov control) gives an isomer (c) such as 2-bromobutane. Coupling of n-butyl bromide with sodium (Wurtz reaction) forms n-octane (d).
explanation: The reactions illustrate competing pathways: elimination of HBr leads to an alkene; subsequent addition of HBr gives a different regioisomer; and the Wurtz reaction couples two alkyl halide molecules to form a higher alkane. The structural formulas and balanced equations must be provided according to the experimental conditions.

question_text: What happens when (i) n-butyl chloride is treated with alcoholic KOH, (ii) bromobenzene is treated with Mg in the presence of dry ether, (iii) chlorobenzene is subjected to hydrolysis, (iv) ethyl chloride is treated with aqueous KOH, (v) methyl bromide is treated with sodium in the presence of dry ether, (vi) methyl chloride is treated with KCN?
correct_answer: (i) n-Butyl chloride reacts via an E2/elimination mechanism to yield butene, (ii) bromobenzene reacts with magnesium to form phenylmagnesium bromide (a Grignard reagent), (iii) chlorobenzene is resistant to hydrolysis due to its partial double bond character, (iv) ethyl chloride undergoes nucleophilic substitution to form ethanol, (v) methyl bromide reacts in the Wurtz reaction forming ethane, (vi) methyl chloride with KCN leads to nucleophilic substitution forming methyl cyanide.
explanation: Each reaction outcome is dictated by the substrate, reagent, and reaction conditions. For example, aromatic halides resist nucleophilic attack due to resonance stabilization, while alkyl halides undergo substitution or elimination depending on the conditions. The formation of Grignard reagents, Wurtz coupling, and nucleophilic substitutions are all governed by the mechanisms discussed in the chapter.
